Package swingtree.api.mvvm

Interface Val<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - The type of the value held by this Val.
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Var<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractVariable
    public interface Val<T>
    A read only view on a value which can be observed by the Swing-Tree UI to dynamically update UI components for you. The API of this is very similar to the Optional API in the sense that it is a wrapper around a value which can be empty or not. Use the onShow(Consumer) method to register a callbacks which will be called when the show() method is called.

    Please take a look at the living swing-tree documentation where you can browse a large collection of examples demonstrating how to use the API of this class.

      Modifier and Type Method Description
      boolean allowsNull()  
      static boolean equals​(java.lang.Object o1, java.lang.Object o2)
      The values of Val and Var implementations ought to be viewed as wrapper for data centric quasi value types! Two arrays of integer for example would not be recognized as equal when calling one of their Object.equals(Object) methods.
      default T get()
      This method is intended to be used for when you want to wrap non-nullable types.
      static int hashCode​(java.lang.Object o)
      Val and Var implementations require their own Object.hashCode() method because they are supposed to be viewed as data centric quasi value types! So two arrays of integer for example would not have the same hash code when calling Object.hashCode() on them.
      default boolean hasID()  
      default boolean hasNoID()  
      java.lang.String id()
      This returns the name/id of the Var which is useful for debugging as well as persisting their state by using them as keys for whatever storage data structure one chooses.

      If a value is present, performs the given action with the value, otherwise does nothing.

    • Method Detail

      • ofNullable

        static <T> Val<T> ofNullable​(java.lang.Class<T> type,
                             T value)
        Use this factory method to create a new Val instance whose value may or may not be null.

        Example: 

        
      Val.ofNullable(String.class, null);

        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the wrapped value.
        Parameters:
        type - The type of the value wrapped by the property. This is used to check if the value is of the correct type.
        value - The initial value of the property. This may be null.
        Returns:
        A new Val instance.

      • of

        static <T> Val<T> of​(T iniValue)
        This factory method will expose a builder which will create a very simple type of Property, namely: AbstractVariable! It has a simple implementation for everything defined in the Var interface. It is similar to an Optional with the additional feature of being mutable as well as being able to be observed for changes.
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the value held by the Var!
        Parameters:
        iniValue - The initial value set to the instance built by this builder. Note: An initialization will overwrite this.
        Returns:
        The builder for a AbstractVariable.

      • get

        default T get()
        This method is intended to be used for when you want to wrap non-nullable types. So if a value is present, it returns the value, otherwise however NoSuchElementException will be thrown. If you simply want to get the value of this property irrespective of it being null or not, use orElseNull() to avoid an exception. However, if this property wraps a nullable type, which is not intended to be null, please use orElseThrow() to make this intention clear. The orElseThrow() method is functionally identical to this method.
        Returns:
        the non-null value described by this Val
        Throws:
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if no value is present

      • orElseNullable

        T orElseNullable​(T other)
        If a value is present, returns the value, otherwise returns other.
        Parameters:
        other - the value to be returned, if no value is present. May be null.
        Returns:
        the value, if present, otherwise other

      • orElse

        default T orElse​(T other)
        If a value is present, returns the value, otherwise returns other.
        Parameters:
        other - the value to be returned, if no value is present. May not be null.
        Returns:
        the value, if present, otherwise other

      • orElseGet

        default T orElseGet​(java.util.function.Supplier<? extends T> supplier)
        If a value is present, returns the value, otherwise returns the result produced by the supplying function.
        Parameters:
        supplier - the supplying function that produces a value to be returned
        Returns:
        the value, if present, otherwise the result produced by the supplying function
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if no value is present and the supplying function is null

      • orElseNull

        default T orElseNull()
        If a value is present, returns the value, otherwise returns null.
        Returns:
        the value, if present, otherwise null

        T orElseThrow()
        If a value is present, returns the value, otherwise throws NoSuchElementException.
        Returns:
        the non-null value described by this Val
        Throws:
        java.util.NoSuchElementException - if no value is present

      • isPresent

        boolean isPresent()
        If a value is present, returns true, otherwise false.
        Returns:
        true if a value is present, otherwise false

      • isEmpty

        default boolean isEmpty()
        If a value is not present, returns true, otherwise false.
        Returns:
        true if a value is not present, otherwise false

      • ifPresent

        default void ifPresent​(java.util.function.Consumer<T> action)
        If a value is present, performs the given action with the value, otherwise does nothing.
        Parameters:
        action - the action to be performed, if a value is present
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if value is present and the given action is null

      • ifPresentOrElse

        default void ifPresentOrElse​(java.util.function.Consumer<? super T> action,
                             java.lang.Runnable emptyAction)
        If a value is present, performs the given action with the value, otherwise performs the given empty-based action.
        Parameters:
        action - the action to be performed, if a value is present
        emptyAction - the empty-based action to be performed, if no value is present
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if a value is present and the given action is null, or no value is present and the given empty-based action is null.

      • or

        default Val<T> or​(java.util.function.Supplier<? extends Val<? extends T>> supplier)
        If a value is present, returns a Val describing the value, otherwise returns a Val produced by the supplying function.
        Parameters:
        supplier - the supplying function that produces a Val to be returned
        Returns:
        returns a Val describing the value of this Val, if a value is present, otherwise a Val produced by the supplying function.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the supplying function is null or produces a null result

      • map

        <V> Val<V> map​(java.util.function.Function<T,​V> mapper)
        Essentially the same as Optional.map(Function). but with a Val as return type.
        Type Parameters:
        V - The type of the value returned from the mapping function
        Parameters:
        mapper - the mapping function to apply to a value, if present
        Returns:
        the result of applying an Optional-bearing mapping

        Type Parameters:

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the result of applying an Optional-bearing mapping

      • valueAsString

        default java.lang.String valueAsString()
        This method simply returns a String representation of the wrapped value which would otherwise be accessed via the orElseThrow() method. Calling it should not have any side effects.
        Returns:
        The String representation of the value wrapped by an implementation of this interface.

      • typeAsString

        default java.lang.String typeAsString()
        This method returns a String representation of the type of the wrapped value. Calling it should not have any side effects.
        Returns:
        A simple String representation of the type of the value wrapped by an implementation of this interface.

      • is

        default boolean is​(T otherValue)
        This method check if the provided value is equal to the value wrapped by this Var instance.
        Parameters:
        otherValue - The other value of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the provided value is equal to the wrapped value.

      • isOneOf

        default boolean isOneOf​(T first,
                        T second,
                        T... otherValues)
        This method check if at least one of the provided values is equal to the value wrapped by this Var instance.
        Parameters:
        first - The first value of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        second - The second value of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        otherValues - The other values of the same type as is wrapped by this.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the provided value is equal to the wrapped value.

      • id

        java.lang.String id()
        This returns the name/id of the Var which is useful for debugging as well as persisting their state by using them as keys for whatever storage data structure one chooses.
        Returns:
        The id which is assigned to this Var.

      • withID

        Val<T> withID​(java.lang.String id)
        Use this method to create a new property with an id. This id is used to identify the property in the UI or as a key in a map, which is useful when converting your view model to a JSON object, or similar formats.
        Parameters:
        id - The id of the property.
        Returns:
        A new Val instance with the given id.

      • hasNoID

        default boolean hasNoID()
        Returns:
        True when this property has not been assigned an id.

      • hasID

        default boolean hasID()
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if this property has been assigned an id.

      • type

        java.lang.Class<T> type()
        This returns the type of the value wrapped by this Var which can be accessed by calling the orElseThrow() method.
        Returns:
        The type of the value wrapped by the Var.

      • toOptional

        default java.util.Optional<T> toOptional()
        Use this to turn this property to an Optional which can be used to interact with the value wrapped by this Var in a more functional way.
        Returns:
        An Optional wrapping the value wrapped by this Var.

      • onShowThis

        Val<T> onShowThis​(UIAction<ValDelegate<T>> displayAction)
        Use this to register an observer lambda which will be called whenever the value wrapped by this Val changes through the Var::set(T) method. The lambda will receive a delegate which not only exposes the current value of this property, but also a fixed number of previous values.
        Parameters:
        displayAction - The lambda which will be called whenever the value wrapped by this Var changes.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • onShow

        default Val<T> onShow​(java.util.function.Consumer<T> displayAction)
        Use this to register an observer lambda which will be called whenever the value wrapped by this Val changes through the Var::set(T) method. The lambda will receive the current value of this property.
        Parameters:
        displayAction - The lambda which will be called whenever the value wrapped by this Var changes.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • show

        Val<T> show()
        Triggers the observer lambdas registered through the onShow(Consumer) as well as the onShowThis(swingtree.api.UIAction) methods. This method is called automatically by the Var::set(T) method, and it is supposed to be used by the UI to update the UI components. This is in essence how binding works in Swing-Tree.
        Returns:
        The Val instance itself.

      • allowsNull

        boolean allowsNull()
        Returns:
        If this property can contain null.

      • equals

        static boolean equals​(java.lang.Object o1,
                      java.lang.Object o2)
        The values of Val and Var implementations ought to be viewed as wrapper for data centric quasi value types! Two arrays of integer for example would not be recognized as equal when calling one of their Object.equals(Object) methods. This is because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays! In order to ensure that two Var values are viewed as the same values simply when the data is identical we use the following utility method to account for these exceptional situations...
        Parameters:
        o1 - The first object which ought to be compared to the second one.
        o2 - The second object which ought to be compared to the first one.
        Returns:
        The truth value determining if the objects are equal in terms of their state!

      • hashCode

        static int hashCode​(java.lang.Object o)
        Val and Var implementations require their own Object.hashCode() method because they are supposed to be viewed as data centric quasi value types! So two arrays of integer for example would not have the same hash code when calling Object.hashCode() on them. This is because the method does not compare the contents of the two arrays!
        Parameters:
        o - The object for which a hash code is required.
        Returns:
        The hash code of the object.
